Award.AwardTitle: Support for 2018 Conference on Computational Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Division of Materials Research, together with the Division of Physics and the Division of Astronomical Sciences contribute funds to this award that provides support for the International Conference on Computational Physics, which will be held at the University of California at Davis from July 29th to August 2nd 2018. This is a highly interdisciplinary meeting that brings together a diverse group of leading researchers from academia, national laboratories, and industry, aiming to broadly share advances in computational physics, to facilitate networking among attendees, and to discuss and further general plans for the community. The topics covered span the topical areas of the Divisions involved. NSF support will enable the participation of 12 early-career scientists, who might not otherwise be able to attend.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The XXX (30th) Conference on Computational Physics (CCP2018) took place July 29 - August 2, 2018 at the University of California, Davis.  CCP is a series of conferences held annually under the auspices of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics (IUPAP) on the basis of endorsement by its Commission on Computational Physics (C20).  The purpose of the conference series is to bring together computational scientists working in physics and closely related areas to exchange the latest developments in computational techniques and their applications. The International Advisory Board of 27 computational scientists included members from Austria, Canada, Cyprus, Czech Republic, France, Germany, India, Israel,Russia, South Africa, South Korea, and the United Kingdom.

There were more than 200 attendees from 23 countries at CCP2018.  The conference featured plenary, invited and contributed talks as well as poster presentations in a wide number of subject areas of active interest to the computational physics community.   The full program is available at http://ccp2018.physics.ucdavis.edu/ where details of the eight plenary sessions, 24 parallel sessions, usually headed by one or more invited presentations, and the poster session, are presented, including the associated  abstracts.   The multiple focus areas of CCP2018 included presentations on: materials physics; statistical mechanics and complex systems; soft matter; biological physics; fluid dynamics, turbulence, nanofluidics, and magnetohydrodynamics; quantum many-body physics; quantum computation; lattice field theory in particle and nuclear physics; astrophysics, space-plasma physics, gravitation, and cosmology; computational physics education; novel hardware and software paradigms; energy, environment and climate modeling; machine learning and applications; and algorithm development.   Professor Noa Marom of Carnegie Mellon University was awarded the 2018 IUPAP Young Scientist Prize in Computational Physics for her research on developing and implementing approaches to computationally design materials with desired properties for target applications. She gave a plenary lecture at CCP2018 describing her research. We offer our congratulations and best wishes to Professor Marom for continued success.

The conference participants and their guests were also treated to a stimulating lecture at the conference banquet by Tony DeRose of PIXAR Animation Studios on Computational Physics at PIXAR.  We extend our thanks to Dr. DeRose.

A conference proceedings of approximately 35 papers has been reviewed, overseen by the Chair and two Vice-chairs  of the conference, and sent to the journal for publication.
